elements.main_content:
If you're going to mess around with speculative futuring, please do so with a sense of a kind of solomn responsibility. That doesn't mean you can't have fun, or be a bit quirky. But when you get a bit close to imagining kinetic armed conflict between two nations that have a long history of a somewhat symbiotic relationship, that's not really reading the room very well.
Futuring, speculating, imagining into bloody conflict does not help the present state of things.
Read more in my post The trouble with staying with the trouble when the future is in trouble (or..How to avoid over-imagining into a dystopian future).

elements.main_copy:
There seems to be a lot of interest in the idea of local models, and the idea of having a model that is trained on your own data or the data of your community. Particularly as the corporate foundation models make it increasingly apparent that they will always have a bias, likely towards the interests of their owners, whether that be a corporation or a government. The idea of having a model that is trained on your own data or the data of your community is appealing, and it raises questions about what it means to have a model that is truly representative of your own experiences and knowledge. This is particularly relevant in the context of the recent discussions around the biases present in large language models and the need more nominalist appreciations for what training data is and becomes. Like Grok going crazy every so often and slipping its moorings and going off on South Africa and white genocide, or Claude doing its Golden Gate Bridge thing.
But what does this mean in the context of, you know ‚Äî bedrock knowledge? What happens with the notion of 'common sense' when epistemologies are derived from a range or even infinity of knowledge bases? What happens when the knoweldge base is not a single, monolithic entity but a collection of potentially conflicting perspectives?
Nominalism, a core principle in discussion with the Oraculator Working Group here in the studio, may be ascendant as a way of comprehending wtf is going on/will become of us.

Grounded in the philosophical framework of Entanglement HCI, this paper introduces speculative entanglement, a practical methodology for technology speculation. This approach involves an iterative interplay between designers and technology practitioners, moving from real-world technological development to fictional representation (the design phase) and back to practical application (the use phase).

It's hardly 24 hours before some new workflow or model ‚Äî¬†offline, running locally ‚Äî¬†has evolved in the 'cinematic' space. As soon as go to the mats with the renderstation doing a bit of inevitable jiujitsu to get things configured to try some contorted workflow, something new comes along.
I know this can be 'triggering' for some; I get it. I truly do. There is at the same time something too curious here to simply get angry about, or to simply avoid.
That sample up there is from a new (I guess it still counts as new a few days after it dropped). The model card indicates it will run on a Macbook M2 with 16gb but also on the 4090. Which is just kind of nuts in the same way publishing on a desktop may have seemed nuts.
Decades ago, the newspaper my dad ran had that one guy, long hair, bell bottoms, a moustache sat at a table with Letraset and did paste-ups, which were literally pasting things up. I wonder what the world felt like when they went digital. I can vaguely remember visiting the newspaper. Was he curious? Peeved? Bewildered with wonderment? Resigned?
Are you curious to prototype, speculate, do some artifact creation?
